docs.snippet: Dory Previn, the lyricist for three Oscar-nominated songs who as a composer and performer mined her difficult childhood, bouts of mental illness and a very public divorce to create a potent and influential personal songbook, died on Tuesday at her...
docs.lead_paragraph: Dory Previn, the lyricist for three Oscar-nominated songs who as a composer and performer mined her difficult childhood, bouts of mental illness and a very public divorce to create a potent and influential personal songbook, died on Tuesday at her home in Southfield, Mass. She was 86. Her death was confirmed by her husband, Joby Baker.
docs.abstract: Dory Previn, the lyricist for three Oscar-nominated songs who as a composer and performer created a potent and influential personal songbook, dies at age 86. Photo (M)

headline.main: Dory Previn, Songwriter, Is Dead at 86

docs.snippet: NOON (Sundance) THE POOL (2008) Venkatesh (Venkatesh Chavan), an Indian teenager on the verge of manhood who ekes out a living cleaning hotel rooms and selling plastic bags on the street, becomes obsessed with the shimmering pool of a luxurious ho...
docs.lead_paragraph: NOON (Sundance) THE POOL (2008) Venkatesh (Venkatesh Chavan), an Indian teenager on the verge of manhood who ekes out a living cleaning hotel rooms and selling plastic bags on the street, becomes obsessed with the shimmering pool of a luxurious home in which no one seems to swim. Eventually he approaches the property's owner (Nana Patekar, above right, with Mr. Chavan) and becomes his assistant; the rich man, in turn, promises to become Venkatesh's benefactor if he will move from Goa to Mumbai and go to school. ''At first 'The Pool' suggests an inspirational fable in which a selfless older man rescues a youth from the streets,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this film by Chris Smith, adapted from a short story by Randy Russell. ''But just when you expect the film to turn into a predictable, rose-colored valentine to opportunity and hope, it goes to a deeper, more ambiguous place. Contemplating poverty from Venkatesh's perspective, it understands that his pursuit of upward mobility will require a terrifying leap of faith.'' The film was chosen as a New York Times Critics' Pick. In ''Summer Hours'' (2009), a movie from Olivier Assayas, at 1:45 p.m., Charles Berling and Juliette Binoche play Frédéric and Adrienne, siblings who must decide what to do with their mother's charming country house and cherished art collection after her death. Frédéric wants to keep everything the way it is for the enjoyment of the next generation. Adrienne and another brother (Jérémie Renier) want to sell the house and most of its contents, donating the best paintings and furnishings to the Musée d'Orsay. ''That, in a nutshell, is the dramatic arc of this extraordinary film, which, in spite of its modest scale, tactful manner and potentially dowdy subject matter, is packed nearly to bursting with rich meaning and deep implication,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. 10:55 A.M. (HBO2) SOMEWHERE (2010) In the first entry in a double bill from Sofia Coppola, Johnny Marco (Stephen Dorff) is a movie star existing in a mind-numbing purgatory -- he drinks, he has anonymous sex, he burns rubber in his Ferrari -- at the Chateau Marmont hotel in Hollywood. He finds something to live for after his ex-wife leaves their 11-year-old daughter (Elle Fanning, right, with Mr. Dorff) in his care. Writing in The Times, A. O. Scott described the movie as ''exquisite, melancholy and formally audacious.'' What happens, he added, ''is something marvelous: a film that never raises its voice (its loudest and most assertive sound is that Ferrari) or panders to your emotions, but that nonetheless has the power to refresh your perceptions and deepen your sympathies.'' ''Lost in Translation'' (2003), for which Ms. Coppola won an Oscar for best original screenplay, follows at 12:40 p.m.

docs.snippet: P.& G. is among the manufacturers trying to deliver distinctive new products that pique the curiosity of tech-conscious consumers....
docs.lead_paragraph: P.& G. is among the manufacturers trying to deliver distinctive new products that pique the curiosity of tech-conscious consumers.
docs.abstract: Stuart Elliott Advertising column; Procter & Gamble is set to launch an estimated $150 million advertising campaign to promote Tide Pods, a new type of laundry product sold in single-use tablets that combine detergent, stain remover and brightener; product is indicative of a trend in marketing of continually delivering distinctive products that pique the curiosity of consumers conditioned to expect innovation.

headline.seo: Procter & Gamble Introduces One-Step Laundry Product
headline.main: A Product to Add Sparkle and Pop to Laundry Day

docs.abstract: Top hair stylist and go-to celebrity image maker Ted Gibson, best known for his makeovers on TLC reality show What Not to Wear, describes how, as a gay black man, he struggled to achieve his success in the fashion world.
